title: Pre-Commissurotomy Central Auditory Assessment in a Patient with Intractable Seizures
chief_complaint: Patient presents for evaluation prior to scheduled commissurotomy due to intractable seizure disorder.

problem_summary.course: Intractable; initially right-sided focus, eventually became generalized. Recently experienced 8 episodes in 3 days.
problem_summary.laterality: Seizure focus initially right-sided; Auditory deficits show right hemisphere patterns (left ear deficit) with some bilateral involvement.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tonic/clonic movements of all extremities, labored breathing during seizures.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Severe disruption of daily life due to frequency and intensity of seizures.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Pre-surgical evaluation for commissurotomy to control seizures.

history.present_illness: 23-year-old female with a history of intractable seizures since age 6. Seizures typically last 5-10 minutes involving tonic/clonic movements and labored breathing. Recently hospitalized with 8 episodes in 3 days.
history.otologic_history: No specific mention of peripheral hearing loss history.
history.medical_psych_history: Treated with Dilantin. Scheduled for commissurotomy 4 months after initial admission.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Pure tone thresholds were normal bilaterally from 250 to 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Dichotic Digits Test
tests.key_findings: Revealed a severe left ear deficit and a mild right ear deficit. This pattern raises the possibility of left hemisphere involvement in addition to the known right hemisphere issues.

tests.name: Dichotic Rhyme Test
tests.key_findings: Performance was borderline normal for the left ear and normal for the right ear.

tests.name: Radiologic Evaluation (SPECT and MRI)
tests.key_findings: SPECT showed asymmetrical accumulation in right basal ganglia and right parietal region. MRI indicated a lesion in the area of Heschl's gyrus and inferior parietal region (right hemisphere).

tests.name: EEG
tests.key_findings: Frequent scattered bursts of polyspike and slow wave discharge developed bilaterally, often independently. Greater activity recorded from the right hemisphere.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal peripheral hearing sensitivity but significant central auditory deficits consistent with her neurological history. Behavioral testing revealed a severe left ear deficit on dichotic digits (consistent with the radiologically confirmed right hemisphere lesion affecting Heschl's gyrus and the parietal lobe) and severe bilateral deficits on duration patterns. A mild right ear deficit on dichotic digits and bilateral EEG abnormalities suggest some left hemisphere involvement as well.
counseling_points: Explain that peripheral hearing is normal.
Discuss how the brain processes sound and how the seizure disorder/lesion is affecting auditory processing (specifically in the left ear and temporal patterning).
Review the correlation between the MRI findings (right parietal/Heschl's gyrus) and the left-ear auditory deficits.
Prepare patient for post-operative reassessment following commissurotomy.
notes_for_actor: You are a 23-year-old female with a long history of severe seizures.
You are likely anxious about the upcoming brain surgery (commissurotomy).

You do not report difficulty hearing simple sounds (beeps), but you may have subtle difficulties processing complex information, though the text does not explicitly describe your subjective auditory complaints.
